RE the Monday Reveal: I remarked that JFC had done a nice summary but that Ken Burns could do a 3-parter on Mr. Dulles. This was not intended as a criticism of JFC's write-up, as some may have believed; rather, it was my way of saying that Mr. Dulles had had quite an action-packed life.

Sometimes, the reveal is just a link. I have never criticized those either. I tried doing this Avatar thing once, when JFC and Martin were both MIA (pre-announced). It is super hard, or at least it was for me. I was pleased at how many grid connections I concocted, using parodic extremism (which is no vice). Any kibbitzing I do is nothing more than that. Although if you want to conclude that I think Mr. Burns sometimes extends his material to fill up more DVDs, that is your prerogative.

I can't praise JFC's writeups too much because then Commenters describe me as some sort of BAALISt (which means "idol-worshipper" in this context even if there are legitimate worshippers of BAAL). So I have settled on a habit of non-criticism. If anyone ever suspects I have criticized JFC's reveal, just ask me.

The following is a general principle, inapplicable to any reveal in recent memory: Non-correction of factual errors in a reveal is no virtue. It would be like allowing someone to wrongly question Martin on the definition of circumstantial evidence.

In engineering I have some experience with tiger cubs in the workplace which seems parallel to yours. They are relentlessly efficient at doing the minimum effort necessary to complete the task and expert at understanding the parameters for which they'll be evaluated during performance review.

But there is something else the I've noticed - the high fliers frequently take exception to testing their work. Developing a proper test protocol for your own work is necessary and can be more challenging than developing a fancy product feature. Testing requires creative thinking. You might have to emulate a range of unexpected human responses, for example. I've noticed the elite students don't value testing and are often antagonistic towards test teams who find their defects. Maybe they thought they left testing behind, or it is the shock of their work not being perfect?

My biggest fear is that the same pressure for perfection will corrupt in the workplace, rendering it intolerant of mistakes- thus mistakes will be hidden rather than reported.

As a professor who welcomes many of these young people after they have gone through the insanity of the admissions process, I have a trade secret to reveal. The children of tiger parents immediately give themselves away, sometimes on the first day. The questions they ask are detailed and perceptive, truly impressive, but they only deal with the grading scheme, the percentage and weight given assignments, and on and on and on. They may be fine young people, but often are simply uninteresting.

The idea of playing with ideas, thinking critically, of turning concepts inside out, is almost always the province of the quirky, the interesting, the fearless. These people are headed for distinction and often have no idea how brilliant they are until they get back their first paper. The tiger cub knows how brilliant he or she is, but is often wildly wrong in that self-appraisal.

Parents: Remember that after you've paid for the last SAT prep course, after your child has attended the Johns Hopkins summer camp for kids who want to show admissions committees that they attended Johns Hopkins summer camp, after you've finished sitting shiva when your child scores a 4 instead of a 5 on an AP test, your child joins a community where the first thing they have to do is think completely out of the boxes in which you've packaged them.

They are joining a community where the the biggest sin isn't an "A-."

It's being a bore.
Kudos to the roommate who could have looked the other way.

The topic is racism in the Americas, which includes the Caribbean. Only a person devoid of knowledge re slavery in America would question how heinous it was, from any angle of analysis. The hypocrisy inherent in a slave system where by law "all men are created equal" is unmatched by slavery in nations where no such rights were set in the fundamental documents. Slaves in European and African traditions were often prized possessions, educated, and treated well. Washington ran a nail factory employing boys under the age of ten. Jefferson refused to release his slaves even though he was bequeathed the cash to do so by the Polish American War hero Kosciuszko, because he calculated their value as breeding stock was too high.

Feagin's states plainly that the focus on current details of small time discrimination contribute to the current misunderstanding, this is why he invokes 400 years. You completely miss the point of the article.

In slamming Patrick's reasoned, thoughtful analysis, you, Joe, seem to have forgotten the Second Amendment. 'Rules of behavior' must comport with those constitutional niceties. You are correct that laws regulate many kinds of behavior, many acts, many people. But no laws, whether local or federal, may abridge those rights granted by the US Constitution.

It's not a completely decided issue, the extent to which government may regulate guns, but owning them in this country is a right, not merely a privilege.

While the article may be accurate, it was ill designed to convince a white audience. Accepting the view point of the interview, look at the interview in context of a white racial frame.

Looking at just two questions the interview discusses how white students viewed racism from an institutional or societal perspective while black students viewed it more individually. In the interview this observation is cast in the context of a white culture that is continually if even unknowingly racist contrasting with individual black victims. It could be recast in the white frame as "whites view racism as institutional and can confront it as such while it remains personal for blacks". I think this is what some of the comments you complain about do. My best attempt at a truly neutral statement might be: "for whites racism generally exists apart from themselves, for blacks race exists as a part of themselves."

The same framing runs through the piece. It's not making its point aggressively, but it's easy to recognize as existing outside the white frame. The interview even touches on the white rejection of other, so both people in the interview must know it won't be effective in reaching many whites. I don't think that's its purpose though.

I think that excessively punishes depressed people for seeking help.

How about passing a law that says if you have a gun in your possession during the commission of a crime you get 20 years in the pokey just for the gun. No parole, no adjustment of term, the full 20 years. Second offense, 40 years. There would be no three time offenders.

That might cut down on the misue of guns.
